currency_notes: I don't think this has subunits and does not need decimal conversion.
Currency of Austria from 1925-1938 and from 1945-1999, comprising 100 Groschen
Several types of French coin issued from the 13th century up until the French Revolution. Can be 1/2, 1/4, or 1/8. If this currency has subunits, then they are sols and they are 60 sols in 1 écu.
Also known as the Rhinegulden, Reichgulden, generally comprised 60 kreutzer. 4 pfennig in 1 kreutzer and 60 kreutzer in 1 German florin240 Pfennig = 60 Kreuzer = 1 Gulden
No subunits, but can have fractions. British coin minted between 1663 and 1814. Between 1717 and 1816, value officially set at 21 shillings.
Danish krone (crown), standardized in 1619. 100 øre in 1 krone. 1/2 krone=50 øre.
Also known as "livres tournois", a unit of account in early modern France, comprising 20 sous (or sols) to a livre, and 12 deniers to a sou
French coins first introduced by Louis XIII in 1640
Currency in Germany between 1924 and 1938, comprising 100 Reichspfennig
Thaler of the Holy Roman Empire. Different states within the empire would produce reichsthalers with different subunits. For our purposes, 60 Kreuzer in 1 Reichsthaler.
Silver coin used across the Holy Roman Empire.
United States dollars
Pound sterling, non-decimal until 1971. 12 pence in 1 shilling and 20 shillings in 1 pound
100 centimes in 1 franc
French francs
1625-1813. Non-decimal. Can have up to four denominations (in GPI data?). 12 pennings in 1 skilling, 16 skillings in 1 mark, and 6 marks in 1 rigsdaler
Also called florins or guldens. Non-decimal until 1817. Decimalized in 1817. 16 penningen in 1 stuiver and 20 stuivers in 1 guilder
1892-1919. 100 Heller in 1 Krone
1919-1925. 100 Heller in 1 Krone

decimal_conversion: (pre-decimal) 1 Mark = 16 schillings; if there is a decimal point, treat as a decimal currency
currency_notes: Marks/Goldmarks/Deutsche Mark/Deutsche Goldmark. Until 1871 16 schillings in 1 Mark. After 1871 Marks are decimal
Unclear if this is different from the other Kronen currencies, but it is probably also a decimal currency.
We currently have "Tschekoslowakische Kronen," which must be Czechoslovak koruna. This was a decimal currency.
I don't think this is in Sales. Possibly in Inventories? It is similar to thalers, with a subunit of 30 to 1.
